questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but is concerned about whitish lesions that recently appeared on his tongue. The lesions are painless and do not cause any discomfort but “look weird.” He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has been sexually active with one female partner and two male partners during the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcoholic beverages. Ten years ago, he experimented with intravenous drugs but “it was a one-time thing.” His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of his mouth is shown. The lesions are nontender and do not come off when scraped with a tongue blade. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. HIV antibody test is positive and CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 380/mm3. Serologic studies for hepatitis B and C are negative. In addition to initiating combined antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of the oral lesions?

choices.text: No additional management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intralesional chemotherapy can be used to treat oral Kaposi sarcoma, which can manifest with painless oral lesions in patients with HIV. However, the lesions in oral Kaposi sarcoma are typically dark (e.g., purple) rather than white and feathery.
Image Description:

Photographs of the oral cavity

Image 1 shows a single purple nodule on the palate.
Image 2 shows several purple papules on the palate.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin can be used to treat oral candidiasis (thrush), which often affects patients with HIV and manifests with nontender white oral lesions. However, oral candidiasis can typically be scraped off, leaving a bleeding base on the oral mucosa. While oral candidiasis is usually a clinical diagnosis, potassium hydroxide may be applied to look for pseudohyphae (characteristic of oral candidiasis) to distinguish between oral candidiasis and OHL.
Image Description:

There are extensive whitish patches that can be scraped off covering the tongue.

This is the typical appearance of pseudomembranous candidiasis, and diagnosis should be confirmed by microscopy and culture of mucosal swabs.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is recommended for the management of leukoplakia, which is a premalignant lesion that manifests with nontender white oral lesions that do not scrape off easily. However, leukoplakia typically manifests with uniformly white plaques, unlike the feathery plaques seen in OHL, and is strongly associated with smoking.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral clobetasol is typically used to treat oral lichen planus, which manifests with white oral lesions. However, oral lichen planus typically manifests with white lacy plaques and is often painful. Moreover, it is strongly associated with hepatitis C.
Image Description:

Lacelike, white lesions on the oral mucous membrane that cannot be scraped off (Wickham striae) are visible.

This appearance is typical for oral lichen planus.

E) CORRECT:

OHL is a benign condition that typically manifests with a feathery or hairy appearance. It is most commonly found on the lateral aspect of the tongue and, less commonly, on the floor of the mouth, palate, or buccal mucosa. OHL is strongly associated with immunosuppressive states, e.g., in patients with HIV, those undergoing chemotherapy, and organ transplant recipients. Therefore, all patients with OHL should be tested for HIV. OHL is self-limited and typically improves after antiretroviral therapy has been initiated; therefore, no additional management is indicated.
questions.hint: Nontender white oral lesions that cannot be removed by scraping in a patient with HIV are highly suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who has had an ulcer on his tongue for approximately 2 months reports increasing pain at the site in recent weeks. He has a history of heavy alcohol and tobacco use. He has been sexually active with multiple partners and had a negative HIV test 3 months ago.
On examination, there is a discrete ulcerated, nodular lesion with white exudate on the ventral surface of his tongue (figure). There is no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia is an opportunistic infection caused by the Epstein-Barr virus in immunocompromised patients, usually people with HIV. It appears as a white, corrugated, hairy-looking area on the side of the tongue that cannot be removed by scraping.

B) INCORRECT:

Secondary syphilis may manifest with a diffuse rash involving the palms and soles and with flat, broad, whitish, wart-like lesions (condyloma latum) on mucous membranes. The acute symptoms resolve within 3 to 6 weeks.

C) CORRECT:

Given the patient’s age, heavy alcohol and tobacco use, and nonhealing oral ulcer with white exudate, the leading diagnosis is squamous-cell carcinoma. Squamous-cell carcinomas of the oral cavity tend to manifest as nonhealing papules, erosions, or ulcerations, frequently with associated pain. Up to 80% of squamous-cell carcinomas of the head and neck occur in individuals with a history of alcohol and tobacco use.

Key learning point: A painful nonhealing papule, erosion, or ulceration in the mouth is most consistent with a diagnosis of squamous-cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Behçet disease is a rare immune-mediated, small-vessel systemic vasculitis that often manifests with oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Visceral organs may also become involved. The recurrent oral ulcerations may last as long as 3 weeks but not 2 months. Behçet disease typically manifests in patients in their 20s.

E) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a common inflammatory disease of unknown etiology that involves the skin and mucous membranes. Oral lichen planus usually manifests as a white, lacy pattern on the dorsal tongue or as shallow red ulcers. It generally occurs in older patients as a result of chronic trauma or medication exposures.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with no known medical history reports having painless white lesions on his tongue for approximately 2 months (figure). He says that the lesions have intermittently changed location on his tongue. He has had no change in his sense of taste and no odynophagia or dysphagia. When seen for preventive-care screening 6 months ago, he had a negative HIV test. He does not use tobacco products.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Geographic tongue, or benign migratory glossitis, is estimated to affect 2% of the world’s population. The typical appearance is map-like patches of erythema on the dorsal aspect of the tongue, with a white hyperkeratotic rim. The condition affects the epithelial layer, resulting in loss of papillae, and can be migratory, changing location and appearance within minutes to hours. A biopsy is generally unnecessary. The condition is asymptomatic, and no therapy is required. Geographic tongue may be observed in patients with psoriasis and atopic dermatitis but also occurs in otherwise healthy individuals, often as an incidental finding.

Key learning point: Found on the dorsal surface of the tongue, erythematous patches with white hyperkeratotic rims are most likely to be consistent with geographic tongue (also known as benign migratory glossitis).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral leukoplakia is a chronic, premalignant condition arising from squamous-cell hyperplasia, generally in older patients in the setting of tobacco use or chronic trauma. The lesions often appear as patches or plaques of the oral mucosa. They do not typically have circinate, geometric borders, and they are not migratory. They are fixed in location but can grow in size and shape.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral lichen planus typically manifests bilaterally and in an older population, frequently in the setting of chronic trauma or medication exposures. Lesions can range from reticular white plaques of the oral mucosa to erosions and ulcerations, which may be painful.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral candidiasis tends to manifest as nonadherent white plaques or pseudomembranes, frequently associated with loss of taste and, possibly, odynophagia. If Candida is considered, a tongue scraping prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) and observed under light microscopy is diagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia manifests as adherent white plaques, typically in people with HIV, related to infection with Epstein-Barr virus. These painless plaques most often affect the lateral portions of the tongue and are not premalignant.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with a painless, nonulcerated white patch on her tongue that she first noticed approximately one month ago. She has never smoked cigarettes or used smokeless tobacco products.
Physical examination confirms a white, corrugated, adherent lesion on the ventral and lateral surface of the tongue; it cannot be scraped off. An HIV test is positive, and the patient’s CD4 count is 260 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia, a mucosal disease related to Epstein-Barr virus infection, is most common in people with HIV but can also occur (less commonly) in patients taking immunosuppressive medications. It is characterized by the appearance of painless, white, adherent plaques that usually involve lateral tongue surfaces. The diagnosis is typically made clinically based on the appearance of these symptoms and their resolution with initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Unlike oral leukoplakia, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered to have malignant potential.

Key learning point: The most typical cause of a white, corrugated, adherent plaque on the lateral surface of the tongue in a person with HIV is oral hairy leukoplakia.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral lichen planus appears as lace-like white patches that occur mainly on the buccal mucosa, often bilaterally. It usually occurs in older patients, frequently in the setting of chronic trauma or medication exposures.

C) INCORRECT:

Black hairy tongue is generally confused with oral hairy leukoplakia only because of its similar name. Black hairy tongue is a benign, painless condition that gives the central, dorsal aspect of the tongue a dark, hairy appearance. It is often associated with poor oral hygiene or recent antibiotic use.

D) INCORRECT:

Oropharyngeal candidiasis typically involves nonadherent white plaques on the buccal mucosa, soft palate, tongue, and/or gums. It is most commonly seen in patients who are immunocompromised, who have received recent antibiotics or chemotherapy, who wear dentures, or who use inhaled glucocorticoids. The diagnosis can be confirmed by scraping the lesion and performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) prep of the scraping.

E) INCORRECT:

Geographic tongue, or benign migratory glossitis, is estimated to affect 2% of the population. It is characterized by a map-like distribution of erythema with a white hyperkeratotic rim, affecting the lateral and dorsal aspects of the tongue. The shape and pattern of appearance can frequently and rapidly change.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with no known medical history reports having painless white lesions on his tongue for approximately 2 years (figure). He says that the lesions have intermittently changed location on his tongue. He has had no change in his sense of taste and no odynophagia or dysphagia
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral candidiasis manifests as nonadherent white plaques or pseudomembranes in healthy infants or immunosuppressed children and adults. It is frequently associated with loss of taste and, possibly, odynophagia. If Candida is considered, a tongue scraping prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) and observed under light microscopy is diagnostic.

B) CORRECT:

Geographic tongue, or benign migratory glossitis, is estimated to affect 2% to 3% of the world’s population. It occurs in all age groups including very young children; however, it is more common in adults. The typical appearance is map-like patches of depapillated erythema on the dorsal aspect of the tongue, with a white hyperkeratotic rim. The condition affects the epithelial layer, resulting in loss of papillae, and can be migratory, changing location and appearance within minutes to hours. A biopsy is generally unnecessary but if performed shows findings identical to pustular psoriasis. The condition is often asymptomatic, although a subset of patients will describe an irritation or burning sensation that may be exacerbated by hot or spicy foods. No therapy is required. Geographic tongue may be observed in patients with psoriasis and atopic dermatitis but also occurs in otherwise healthy individuals, often as an incidental finding.

Key learning point: Found on the dorsal surface of the tongue, erythematous patches with white hyperkeratotic rims are most likely to be consistent with geographic tongue (also known as benign migratory glossitis).

C) INCORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia manifests as painless, adherent white plaques located on the lateral aspects of the tongue, typically in immunosuppressed individuals with HIV infection. It is related to infection with Epstein-Barr virus and is not seen in healthy, immunocompetent children.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral lichen planus may occur at any age and typically manifests with whitish, thread-like, reticulate or confluent patches on the buccal mucosa. It may also manifest as painful erosions and ulcerations. It does not feature geographic, migratory denuded red and hyperkeratotic white plaques as seen in geographic tongue.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral leukoplakia is a chronic, premalignant condition arising from squamous-cell hyperplasia. It is associated with genetic conditions in younger patients and with tobacco use or chronic trauma in older adult patients. The lesions often appear as whitish patches or plaques of the oral mucosa. They do not typically have circinate, geometric borders, and they are not migratory. They are fixed in location but can grow in size and shape over time. Oral leukoplakia may be observed in children with dyskeratosis congenita (premalignant) and pachyonychia congenita (not premalignant), but it is extremely rare in otherwise healthy children and adolescents.
